DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Little Changed in Light Early Trading
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were little changed in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade with no significant news to move prices. ``It's pretty much dead in the water,'' said Joel Karlin, an analyst with Research Department Inc., a Chicago-based brokers' advisory service. A slight early decline in the soybean market reflected some profit-taking after Thursday's strong gains, which were fueled by expectations of new sales of U.S. soybean meal to Eastern European countries. Corn futures also were fractionally lower while the wheat market was narrowly mixed. The markets were scheduled to close early, at noon CST, today, the last trading day of 1989. In early trading, wheat futures were { cent lower to } cent higher with the contract for delivery in March at $4.08} a bushel; corn was unchanged to } cent lower with March at $2.39{ a bushel; oats were { cent higher across the board with March at $1.54{ a bushel; soybeans were { cent lower to 1 cent higher with January at $5.68} a bushel. Cattle futures were mostly higher and pork futures mostly lower in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were unchanged to .15 cent higher with February at 77.37 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .20 cent lower to .15 cent higher with January at 84.80 cents a pound; live hogs were .05 cent to .12 cent lower with February at 48.80 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .20 cent lower to .35 cent higher with February at 49.70 cents a pound. Livestock futures settled lower on Thursday while pork bellies advanced.
